National Nanotechnology Center National Science and Technology Development Agency 111 Thailand Science Park Pathumthani 12120 Thailand Graphical abstract The catalysts of copper aluminates (CuAl2O4), copper oxide (CuO), and alumina (Al2O3) synthesized via one-step flame-spray pyrolysis (FSP) with various mole ratios of Cu to Al have been studied in the hydrogenolysis of glycerol, a byproduct from the biodiesel industry, to 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO) at 220 °C under 50 bar of H2 for 6 h. The studies on the CuAl2O4 nanoparticles reveal that their formation and particle size depend upon the mole ratio of Cu to Al, and they possess a structure analogous to that of the bulk material. The X-ray absorption near edge spectroscopy (XANES) data along with X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns confirmed the formation of a CuAl2O4–CuO–Al2O3 mixed phases. The characteristic CuAl2O4 species was dominant during the flame process when a low content of Cu to Al, such as a 1:5 mol ratio, was supplied. It was observed that the CuAl2O4 combined with the CuO and Al2O3 phases exerts a strong positive effect on the catalytic activity. A selectivity to 1,2-PDO of 91.7% was observed for the synthesized catalyst with a 1:1 mole ratio of Cu to Al. The developed catalyst was superior to the conventional CuO-based ones in the hydrogenolysis of glycerol process. Keywords Flame-spray pyrolysis CuAl2O4 XANES Glycerol hydrogenolysis 1,2-Propanediol 1 Introduction Glycerol is a major by-product during the production of biodiesel; it constitutes ca. 10 wt% of the total biodiesel yield [1–3]. With increasing biodiesel production, the large surplus of glycerol is continuously produced and leads to a significant decrease in the price of glycerol [4,5]. Thus, research has been conducted to discover new applications for glycerol as a low-cost feedstock, in which glycerol can be converted into commercially valued products [2,6,7]. A value-added opportunity is required to compensate for the disposal-associated costs, such as the catalytic glycerol conversion to lactic acid [8,9], glyceric acid [10], acrolein [11,12], glycerol carbonate [13] and 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO) [14–16]. Additionally, the conversion of glycerol to 1,2-PDO through a hydrogenolysis reaction has attracted significant attention because it is widely used in the production of polyester resins, functional fluids, cosmetics, pharmaceuticals and food products [17,18]. The hydrogenolysis of glycerol typically involves two major reactions, namely, 1) deoxygenation of glycerol via dehydration pathway removing oxygen and hydrogen species in form of water and 2) hydrogenation saturating the double bond of its parent molecules. Several studies have reported that glycerol hydrogenolysis can be performed in both gaseous and liquid phases using oxide catalyst [19,20] or metal catalysts such as Pt [21,22], Ru [23], Ni [3,24] and Cu [5,25,26]. Among these catalysts, Cu-based catalysts are preferred for this reaction because they are selective to CO bond cleavage and have a low activity for cleaving CC bonds in the presence of H2 [27,28], resulting in high selectivity for the 1,2-PDO. The copper catalysts are more cost effective than the noble metal ones. In addition, Mane and Rode [29] observed that spinel-type copper catalysts, especially copper aluminate (CuAl2O4), exhibited excellent activity for simultaneous glycerol dehydration and its hydrogenolysis without external hydrogen. Various conventional methods, including the impregnation, precipitation and sol-gel method, have been applied for the preparation of CuAl2O4 catalysts [30,31]. However, these methods are batch processes that require several post-treatment steps, such as filtration, drying and calcination. Consequently, flame-spray pyrolysis (FSP) is an interesting technique to synthesize nanoparticles in a one-step process, especially for the synthesis of a wide variety of metal oxide catalysts with high purity and production rate [32,33]. Furthermore, this technique can also generate an elaborate catalyst shape with a high surface area and high metal dispersion, leading to catalyst resistance to sintering and coking [34,35]. Another researcher reported that the flame-synthesized catalyst exhibited better catalytic performance than one prepared by a conventional method [36]. It should be noted that the one-step flame-spray pyrolysis opens up a promising pathway for catalyst preparation that is cost-efficient, easily scalable and reproducible. However, it is noteworthy that the CuAl2O4 may contain metals in more than one oxide form at different Cu to Al mole ratios. It becomes important to know the proportion of the mixed oxides in the sample. This issue can be solved using X-ray absorption near edge spectroscopy (XANES). This technique can distinguish the proportions of the mixed oxides in the sample and can also yield the oxidation state, the local structure and the electronic environment of the atom absorbing the X-rays. So, the composition of CuO and CuAl2O4 phases on the catalyst can be adjusted by varying Cu loading in FSP process. The presence of both CuO and CuAl2O4 may prove to be synergistically effective for the catalytic activity. Thus, in this investigation, we show that CuAl2O4 catalysts can be prepared by one-step flame-spray pyrolysis with various molar ratios of Cu to Al. We also report detailed characterization of the catalysts by X-ray diffraction (XRD), H2-temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), N2 sorption isotherm analysis and N2O pulse chemisorption to elucidate the physicochemical properties and identify the active species of the catalysts. We further examined the formation of CuAl2O4 nanoparticles using Cu K-edge X-ray absorption near edge spectroscopy (XANES). The data were analyzed to yield the proportions of the mixed oxides in the sample by linear combination fitting (LCF). Then the series of the FSP-made catalysts was tested in the liquid-phase glycerol hydrogenation to 1,2-PDO. The composition of the copper spinel-oxide, copper-oxide, and alumina was found to be important for a synergistic effect on the reaction when the best composition gave great 1,2-PDO selectivity of 91.7%. The information gained here demonstrates the great potential for developing an effective catalyst for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-PDO. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The CuAl2O4 catalysts with the desired mole ratio of Cu to Al were prepared by flame-spray pyrolysis (FSP), using aluminum-tri-sec-butoxide (Sigma-Aldrich, 97 wt%) and copper(II) 2-ethylhexanoate (Sigma-Aldrich, 99 wt%) as precursors. In a typical synthesis, stoichiometric quantities of Al and Cu precursors were dissolved in xylene. The total concentration of metal species was constant at 0.15 M. Then, the liquid mixture was loaded in a syringe and placed in a syringe pump, followed by injection through the center capillary of the FSP nozzle with a flow rate of 5 mL/min. An O2 stream was fed through the surrounding annulus at 5 dm3/min, generating droplets of the solution. The pressure drop at the nozzle was held constant at 1.5 bar by adjusting the annulus-gap width. The spray was ignited by (i) a supporting flame fed with an O2-flame (3 dm3/min) and CH4 (1.5 dm3/min) positioned in a ring around the nozzle outlet and (ii) an O2-sheath (10 dm3/min) provided through a sintered metal plate ring to support the flame. The solid materials were collected with a glass fiber filter with the aid of a vacuum pump and were labelled in the form xCuyAl, where x and y refer to the moles of Cu and Al, respectively. In addition, the pure Al2O3 was synthesized by the same method without adding Cu precursor, and the pure CuO catalyst was synthesized without adding Al precursor. 2.2 Catalyst characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were obtained using a powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD–Bruker; D8 Advance) coupled with a Cu Kα radiation source (λ=0.15406 nm). The measurements were conducted at 40 kV, 40 mA, and intervals of 0.02° s−1. The X-ray absorption near edge structure (XANES) spectra were recorded at the BL-5.2 SUT-NANOTEC-SLRI XAS Beamline of the Synchrotron Light Research Institute (Public Organization), Thailand using a double Ge (2 2 0) crystal monochromator for the selection of photon energy. The data were obtained at room temperature in transmission mode. The photon energy was calibrated by a Cu foil at 8979.0 eV and scanned from −30 eV below the edge to +80 eV above the edge. The XANES spectra were analyzed using the Athena program. The temperature-programmed reduction (TPR) was conducted using a Quantachrome ChemBET™ Pulsar Chemisorption Analyzer. The catalyst sample was placed in a U-shaped quartz reactor and pretreated in flowing He (30 cm3/min) at 120 °C for 30 min and then cooled to room temperature. After pretreatment, a 5% H2/Ar mixture gas under a flow rate of 30 cm3/min was contacted with the sample while heating from room temperature to 850 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min. The BET surface area, pore volume and pore-size distribution were measured by the conventional BET method with N2 sorption using a NOVA 2000e analyzer. Prior to N2 adsorption, the sample was degassed at 150 °C for 3 h to remove the moisture adsorbed on the surface and inside the pores. The copper metal surface area, copper particle size and metal dispersion were determined by N2O pulse chemisorption using the same apparatus as for the TPR, equipped with a mass spectrometer (ThermoStar™ gas analysis system). Before N2O adsorption, the sample was reduced in 5% H2/Ar at 300 °C for 3 h. A 50 mm3 aliquot of N2O was injected into the injection port to adsorb onto the metal surface of the sample at 60 °C. Injection of N2O was continuously repeated until saturation. The amount of carbonaceous deposit on the catalyst after reaction test was determined using carbon-hydrogen-nitrogen elemental analyzer (CHN analyzer; CHN628, LECO, Japan). The morphology of the samples was obtained by a transmission electron microscopy (TEM; JEM-2100 JEOL, Japan) with an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. The sample was dispersed in ethanol to obtain the uniform dispersion of the sample. A drop of liquid was deposited onto a copper mesh sample grid covered by a holey carbon film. 2.3 Catalytic-activity measurement The catalytic activity of the prepared catalysts was measured in a stainless steel autoclave equipped with a Teflon inner layer (75 mL) and thermoelectric couple. Prior to reaction, the catalyst was reduced in a stream of 10% H2/N2 at 300 °C for 3 h. Then, 10 g of glycerol (Sigma-Aldrich, 99.5%) was added into the reactor, and the reaction system was free of additional solvent. The solvent-free system would provide advantages on reactor sizing and downstream processing. Next, the reactor was purged and pressurized with H2 atmosphere. The reaction was conducted at 220 °C and 50 bar in H2 for 6 h under vigorous stirring (1000 rpm). After the reaction, the reactor was cooled to room temperature with ice water, and the gas was released slowly. The liquid phase was centrifuged to remove the solid catalyst and was analyzed using a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu GC-2014) equipped with a 30 m capillary column (DB-WAX 52 CB, USA) and a flame ionization detector (FID). The glycerol conversion is defined as the ratio of the number of moles of glycerol converted in the reaction to the total initial moles of glycerol. The yield of 1,2-PDO is defined as the ratio of the number of moles of 1,2-PDO formed to the initial number of moles of glycerol. The glycerol conversion, yield, and selectivity are defined by Eqs. (1)–(3), respectively. The Al2O3 sample exhibited the characteristic peak of γ-Al2O3 (JCPDS card no. 29-63) and α-Al2O3 (JCPDS card no. 82-1468) [37], and the CuO sample exhibited sharp diffraction peaks, especially at 35.5° and 38.7°, which can be indexed to the monoclinic phase of bulk CuO (JCPDS no. 45-0937) [38]. In contrast, the XRD patterns of all of the fresh xCuyAl samples were not clearly distinguishable. In the case of 2Cu1Al and 1Cu1Al, the XRD patterns revealed dominant peaks at 35.5° and 38.7° that could be attributed to an excess of the CuO phase. However, along with the appearance of new maxima, the reduction of the characteristic peaks corresponding to the CuO phase was observed for the 1Cu3Al and 1Cu5Al catalysts. This could be due to the low copper content in the samples or to highly dispersed CuO nanoparticles [39]. The intense peaks at 36.6° and 45.3° can be assigned to either CuAl2O4 spinel (JCPDS card no. 33-0448) [40] or γ-Al2O3, while the positions and peak intensities of their patterns were similar. In the high temperature zone of flame pyrolysis, the formation of alumina phase and copper aluminate one could be expected. However, it was difficult to confirm the chemical and structural phase of the catalysts based only on the XRD characteristics. Fortunately, this problem can be resolved by XANES. To investigate the proportions of the copper oxides in the sample, XANES spectra at the Cu K-edge of all of the catalysts were collected (Fig. 2 a). In the present work, we have chosen reference materials, including CuO and CuAl2O4 as the two copper-based species, and we have acquired their XANES spectra separately. Generally, the XANES spectrum of CuO exhibits a characteristic shoulder feature at 8984 eV that is attributed to the 1s→4pz (shakedown) transition, but this peak was not observed in the CuAl2O4 spinel. The shape and features of the samples were similar to both the spectra of CuO and CuAl2O4 spinel, indicating that the samples are in the form of CuAl2O4-CuO nanocatalysts. Hence, their derivative XANES spectra were calculated for comparison, as shown in Fig. 2b. The edge position at the maximum point of the first inflection point for the standard and xCuyAl samples with respect to the Cu metal foil at 8979.0 eV are listed in Table 1. Generally, the absorption-edge position can be related to the oxidation state of the absorbing atom: a shift of the absorption edge to higher energies indicates a higher oxidation state. For metallic Cu (8979.0 eV), Cu 2O (8980.0 eV) and CuO (8983.5 eV) species, the values differ by 1.0 eV and 2.3 eV, respectively, as reported in the literature [41,42]. In the case of xCuyAl catalysts, the edge positions of 1Cu1Al and 2Cu1Al were similar to that of the CuO species, whereas the others showed edge positions in the range of the CuO and CuAl2O4 species. A linear combination fit (LCF) of the XANES spectra was applied and performed using XANES data of standard materials (CuO and CuAl2O4) as possible compositions. This procedure yielded the percentage of the oxides in the xCuyAl catalysts. The weight percentages are tabulated in Table 2. The statistical goodness-of-fit parameters, including the R-factor, chi-square and reduced chi-square, show that the fit is reasonably good. The LCF confirmed that the xCuyAl catalysts contained mixed oxides of CuO and CuAl2O4. Consequently, it can be observed that the amount of CuO increased with increasing molar ratio of Cu to Al; in contrast, the amount of CuAl2O4 decreased. Based on XRD and XANES data, CuO and CuAl2O4 along with Al2O3 were three major components in the samples. As also shown in Table 2, alumina co-existed in all samples, except 2Cu1Al. The lower Cu to Al ratios gave rise to higher alumina content in the samples, while 55.4 wt% of alumina was found in 1Cu5Al. 3.1.2 Reducibility To test the catalytic performance of the samples, H2-TPR was selected to study their reducibility. The respective H2-TPR profiles of the xCuyAl catalysts with various molar ratios of Cu to Al are displayed in Fig. 3 . The H2-TPR profiles of samples typically show a reduction peak with a shoulder in the range of 250−340 °C indicating the existence of CuO nanoparticles [42]. The two reduction steps at low temperature are due to the consecutive reduction of the highly dispersed CuO particles to metallic Cu (Cu2+ → Cu+ → Cu°) [43] and the subsequent reduction of CuAl2O4 [31,44]. These results are in excellent agreement with the XRD and XANES studies. The 1Cu3Al, 1Cu2Al, 1Cu1Al and 2Cu1Al samples exhibit a shoulder reduction peak shifted to a high temperature along with increasing molar ratio of Cu to Al. This could be the direct reduction of Cu2+ → Cu° of the bulk CuO which is abundant in the sample. In addition, it should be noted that increasing the molar ratio of Cu to Al can generate more CuO bulk with larger particles [45]. After reduction, however, all of the catalysts presented characteristic peaks of metallic Cu (JCPDS card no. 04-0836) [46] at 43.1°, 50.1° and 73.9° along with the CuAl2O4 peaks but in the absence of the CuO peaks (Fig. 4 ). This indicated that the excess CuO is completely reduced under this reduction condition. The change in phase compositions was due to the sequential reduction of Cu2+ to Cu° during the activation protocol. 3.1.3 Textural properties and morphology The BET specific surface areas of the xCuyAl catalysts are presented in Table 3 . The surface area of xCuyAl catalysts decreased with increasing mole ratio of Cu to Al. This result suggests that the surface and pores of CuAl2O4 are occupied by excess CuO particles, which was confirmed by the LCF of XANES. The N2O pulse chemisorption of the xCuyAl catalysts are summarized in Table 3. It is clear that the particle size of the metallic Cu increased from 20.0–83.5 nm with increasing Cu concentration in the range studied. Accordingly, the corresponding dispersion decreased from 5.18 to 1.23%. The higher Cu loading ratio did not lead to the higher copper surface area due to the formation of larger cluster particles of CuO. TEM images of the xCuyAl catalysts are presented in Fig. 5 . The shape of all catalyst particles was rather spherical in nano-scale. The 1Cu3Al, 1Cu2Al, and 1Cu1Al had a uniform particle size in the range of 5−15 nm; the higher Cu content tends to give a larger size. An agglomeration of the particles was found on 2Cu1Al with the remarked increase in the particle size up to 25−50 nm which is consistent with their specific surface area. Pure CuO shows a large individually particle with a wide size distribution. This result indicated the nanoparticle agglomeration and sintering induced by copper species during the flame process. 3.2 Catalytic tests The catalytic performance of the reduced xCuyAl catalysts for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-PDO (or called propylene glycol) under H2 atmosphere is shown in Fig. 6 . The bare Al2O3 showed the lowest catalytic activity both in terms of the conversion and yield, which indicated that Al2O3 is not active for this reaction. The pure CuO showed a moderate glycerol conversion and 1,2-PDO yield. This is due to the intrinsic properties of the Cu metal, which prefers to cleave the CO bond. In the case of the xCuyAl catalysts, the glycerol conversion continuously increased with increasing molar ratio of Cu to Al from 1:5 to 1:1. Therefore, the 1Cu1Al catalyst showed the highest catalytic activity for glycerol hydrogenolysis with 55.5% conversion and 50.9% yield. This reflected the good selectivity toward the product at 91.7%, when the amount of byproducts was extremely low. At a low Cu content, the major phase of CuAl2O4 could provide activity to a certain value. The higher Cu content gave rise to a higher catalytic activity, although the surface area was lower and the particle size was larger. At a Cu to Al ratio of 1:2 to 1:1, which increased the ratio of CuO to CuAl2O4, a CuO–CuAl2O4–Al2O3 composite catalysts, as evidenced by the XANES and XRD results, providing the best performance. The active site for the reaction was considered metallic copper from both copper-based oxide phases, and both phases would synergistically catalyze the reaction. Although, alumina is not an active phase, its presence would help improve dispersion of the copper species. However, when the molar ratio of Cu to Al further increased to 2:1, the conversion and yield clearly dropped to 29.3% and 24.8%, respectively, according to the formation of CuO bulk due to the excess Cu loading. Clearly, the pure CuO phase did not produce the highest activity, although it had the highest Cu loading. In contrast, too low amount of Cu in 1Cu5Al sample was not sufficient to provide a good activity. These results suggest that a suitable molar ratio of Cu to Al could effectively catalyze the reaction. The high catalytic activity implies a high dispersion of copper nanoparticles on a high surface area of alumina in this catalyst system. In addition, alumina would help facilitate the hydrogenation function of the composite while the copper species catalyze the hydrogenation to produce 1,2-PDO. The proper ratio of these species is a crucial factor to achieve the high product yield. It has been well-accepted that the conversion of glycerol to 1,2-PDO required both acid (or base) sites and metal sizes for dehydration of glycerol to acetol and for hydrogenation of acetol to 1,2-PDO, respectively [25]. As shown in the XRD analysis of the reduced/reacted catalysts (Fig. 4a and b), only the diffraction lines of metallic Cu were observed while there was no diffraction line of CuO. In addition, the diffraction lines representing CuAl2O4 phases showed relatively low intensity compared to those of the calcined catalysts (Fig. 4a and b), suggesting that Cu species in CuAl2O4 was majorly reduced to form metallic copper. The Al2O3 and metallic copper species would act as the active sites for dehydration of glycerol to acetol and hydrogenation of acetol to 1,2-PDO, respectively. Cu(II) species from CuAl2O4 phase in the reduced or reacted catalysts are marginally observed by XRD, although the role of the Cu(II) species is not evidenced. We have conducted the reaction over single component of CuAl2O4 without pre-reduction. As a result, extremely low 1,2-PDO yield was observed without the acetol intermediate, implying that the Cu(II) species did not directly involve in the main reaction. It was previously reported that Cu deposited on CuAl2O4 showed significantly higher activity than Cu deposited in Al2O3 in furfural hydrogenation [47]. The density functional theory calculation suggested that the stronger interaction of copper with reactants and the lower reaction free energy and energy barriers for hydrogenation contribute to the enhanced performance. The reaction temperature had a considerable effect on the glycerol conversion and 1,2-PDO yield. We carried out the hydrogenolysis reaction of pure glycerol without any solvent at elevated temperatures on 1Cu1Al catalyst. As shown in Fig. 7 , glycerol conversion and yield to 1,2-PDO increased from 55.5 to 96.9% and 50.9 to 66.1%, respectively, with increasing reaction temperature from 220 to 240 °C. However, 1,2-PDO can undergo further hydrogenolysis leading to CC bond cleavage and produce ethylene glycol and low molecular alcohols at the higher temperature. As previously reported in the literature, Rasika et al. [48] studied the catalytic performance of Cu:Al catalyst (0.8 g) using 20 wt% glycerol aqueous solution (100 mL) under 70 bar H2 pressure for 5 h. The results showed that glycerol conversion increased from 29 to 76% with increase in temperature from 200 to 240 °C while the selectivity to the 1,2-PDO decreased from 93 to 89%. Malaya et al. [49] also studied the selective hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-PDO of B2O3-promoted Cu/Al2O3 (2.0 g) in continuous down-flow tubular reactor using 10 wt% glycerol aqueous solution under 50 bar H2 pressure and WHSV 0.2 h−1 for 3 h. The authors reported that glycerol conversion improved dramatically from 15 to 99% as the temperature increase from 170 to 270 °C while the 1,2-PDO selectivity decreased from 98 to 85%. It should be noted that the differences in operating conditions and reactor set-up would strongly influence the performance of the catalysts. 3.3 Reusability tests and characterization of the spent catalyst To study the reusability of the catalyst, 1Cu1Al catalyst was chosen to carry out under the same conditions as previously mentioned. In each cycle, the catalyst was removed from the reaction mixture by centrifugation, and washed with DI water several times before drying at 70 °C overnight. The spent catalyst was reduced in a stream of 10% H2/N2 at 300 °C for 3 h prior to the next reaction cycle. From Fig. 8 , the results showed that the glycerol conversion and yield to 1,2-PDO reduced from 55.5 to 43.3% and 50.9 to 20.1%, respectively, after the second reaction cycle. The reaction further proceeded to the next cycle and it was found that the conversion and yield dropped to 16.0% and 8.5%, respectively. By comparing the XRD patterns of the spent catalysts after the first and third cycles, as shown in Fig. 9 , the results clearly showed the decrease in the peak intensity. The particle sizes were calculated by the Scherrer equation to determine the possible sintering of the Cu particles during the reaction driven by the hydrothermal condition used [50]. This equation was applied to the main copper reflection (2θ = 43.3°). The Cu crystallite sizes were 17.8 nm after the first reaction cycle, and 38.0 nm after the third one. Thus, a sintering of the Cu particles was clearly observed for 1Cu1Al catalyst. In addition, the BET surface area of the spent catalyst was found to decrease by 4.4 times compared to the fresh catalyst (from 104.2 to 23.9 m2/g). It was reported that surface defects of the fresh and spent catalysts would cause catalyst poisoning since the residual glycerol blocked the active components, thus making the catalyst inactive [51]. Moreover, the decreasing activity could be attributed to the carbon deposition, leading to a decrease in the number of active components available for the reaction. The carbon content in the spent catalyst was detected by CHN elemental analysis. The carbon content was approximately 5 wt% on the surface of the spent catalyst after 3 reaction cycles. It was considered that coking and metal sintering would be the possible reasons for the catalyst deactivation. 4 Conclusions A series of xCuyAl catalysts with various mole ratios of Cu:Al has been successfully synthesized using the one-step FSP technique. During FSP, the copper species reacted with the aluminum species to form a CuO–CuAl2O4–Al2O3 nanocatalyst. The phase composition of the nanoparticles obtained was strongly dependent on the molar ratio of Cu to Al. The xCuyAl catalysts are highly active for the hydrogenolysis of glycerol and are selective to 1,2-PDO under moderate reaction conditions. The combination of CuO-CuAl2O4–Al2O3 at an optimum Cu to Al ratio synergistically catalyzes the reaction, providing the highest catalytic performance with a high selectivity of 91.7%. The present catalyst was superior to the conventional CuO-based one, and would be a great option for using in glycerol hydrogenolysis process. coredata.dc:description: The catalysts of copper aluminates (CuAl2O4), copper oxide (CuO), and alumina (Al2O3) synthesized via one-step flame-spray pyrolysis (FSP) with various mole ratios of Cu to Al have been studied in the hydrogenolysis of glycerol, a byproduct from the biodiesel industry, to 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PDO) at 220 °C under 50 bar of H2 for 6 h. The studies on the CuAl2O4 nanoparticles reveal that their formation and particle size depend upon the mole ratio of Cu to Al, and they possess a structure analogous to that of the bulk material. The X-ray absorption near edge spectroscopy (XANES) data along with X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns confirmed the formation of a CuAl2O4–CuO–Al2O3 mixed phases. The characteristic CuAl2O4 species was dominant during the flame process when a low content of Cu to Al, such as a 1:5 mol ratio, was supplied. It was observed that the CuAl2O4 combined with the CuO and Al2O3 phases exerts a strong positive effect on the catalytic activity. A selectivity to 1,2-PDO of 91.7% was observed for the synthesized catalyst with a 1:1 mole ratio of Cu to Al. The developed catalyst was superior to the conventional CuO-based ones in the hydrogenolysis of glycerol process.
coredata.dc:title: CuAl2O4–CuO–Al2O3 catalysts prepared by flame-spray pyrolysis for glycerol hydrogenolysis
